results.title: Decades of steam : the 1940's, austerity and nationalisation
results.creator_credit: Ian Allan Limited and Jeremy English
results.brief_description: This is the third in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle years of the 20th century. In this episode the story of steam locomotives is taken through the end of independence into the early days of Nationalisation. The first half of the decade saw the railways at the forefront of the war effort, from which the black painted steam locomotives emerged bloodied but unbowed, still the principal power force on the railways. 1948 was to see a unified system, with Nationalisation. We see them on trial and bearing their new owner’s name in full - “British Railways”. We see postwar type engines and also some prewar survivors including the most radical of all, the Bulleid Pacific of the Southern. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Decades of steam : the 1920's, the big four
results.creator_credit: Ian Allan Limited and Jeremy English
results.brief_description: This is the first in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle years of the 20th century. In this episode we look at the great amalgamation - the grouping - of the Victorian companies in 1923 to form the “Big Four” railways: the Great Western, the Southern, the London, Midland and Scottish and the London & North Eastern. Using previously unseen archival film of the 1920’s, we examine the stock inherited by the “Big Four” and then look at the first new types introduced by the “Big Four”. Many rare scenes are shown and many locomotives shown including the Great Western “Dukes”, the “Lord Nelsons”, the “Atlantics” and the A1 “Pacifics”. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Decade for action
results.brief_description: A report on the United Nations Development Decade which aims to replace labour intensive production methods in third world nations in an attempt to liberate people from hunger and poverty. Focuses on innovative international efforts that have harnessed the energy generated by the sun, wind and water and transformed it into power. By applying these technological achievements and injecting capital, the UN believes it may alleviate many of the hardships endured by underdeveloped nations. Includes a segment on the development of the Volta River Dam.

results.title: Debt to the past: language and communication
results.creator_credit: Moody Institute of Science. Educational Film Division
results.brief_description: This film depicts varied means of communication such as spoken, unspoken and written language: pictographic, ideographic and phonetic. It discusses phonemes and the history of the alphabet. It shows the power language has for good and evil, and stresses the need for humans to use this great gift for worthy and constructive purposes.

results.title: Debs
results.brief_description: In the Republic of Ireland, the “Debs” dance marks the end of school days, a romantic night to remember, which represents the transition from childhood to maturity. The reality, however, is often an expensive evening of heartbreak or alcoholic excess, culminating in the exhausted and dispirited youths trailing through the down streets of Dublin in their bedraggled finery. This look at teenage ritual is explosively portrayed by youngsters from the Dublin Youth Centre.

results.title: Debbie and Robert: 12-24 months (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Robert Humble
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Child”.
Debbie and Robert’s behaviour is typical of the second year of life. Illustrates the process of learning that goes on through every waking hour, and the kind of guidance a parent can give.

results.title: Debating Techniques
results.brief_description: In this program, the formal rules and techniques of Debating are presented in detail. Middle School students are involved in a debate, providing a real context for the presentation of the techniques. The Debate, its format, the role of each team and of each member of the team, are explained and demonstrated. Adjudication of the Debate is included.

results.title: Death: coping with loss
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films, Bill Mackie and Larry Pont
results.brief_description: Presents discussions of fears about dying, terminal illness, responding to loss, funerals and comforting the bereaved. Examines reactions and attitudes of various people towards death.

results.title: Death warmed up
results.creator_credit: Tucker Production Company, Murray Newey and David Blyth
results.brief_description: Michael Tucker (Michael Hurst) is programmed to kill his parents by genetic surgeon, Dr Archer Howell (Gary Day) and is incarcerated in a psychiatric institution for the crime. Years later, Michael and friends travel to an isolated Island where Howell now runs Transcranial Applications, experimenting on humans and turning them into mutant killing machines. Michael seeks revenge on Howell for the death of his parents but also to stop him for the sake of mankind. Co-starring Margaret Umbers, William Upjohn, Norelle Scott, Bruno Lawrence and David Letch.

results.title: Death Star Canteen
results.brief_description: A young American YouTuber animated this stop-motion film to Eddie Izzard’s “Death Star Canteen” comedy bit from Circle.

constellations_other.name: Stop-motion fantasies
constellations_other.description: The LEGO Movie draws on fan-made stop-motion films for its aesthetic style, but fantastical animation comes in many forms.
